pairs.stoic_text:
In 140 Marcus was raised to the consulship, and in 145 his betrothal
was consummated by marriage. Two years later Faustina brought him a
daughter; and soon after the tribunate and other imperial honours were
conferred upon him.
pairs.neutral_text: In 140 CE, Marcus was appointed to the position of consul. In 145 CE, he married his fiancée. Two years after the marriage, Faustina gave birth to a daughter. Shortly afterward, Marcus received the tribunate and other high-ranking government positions.

pairs.stoic_text:
On this journey his wife, Faustina, died. At his return the emperor
celebrated a triumph (176). Immediately afterwards he repaired to
Germany, and took up once more the burden of war. His operations were
followed by complete success; but the troubles of late years had been
too much for his constitution, at no time robust, and on March 17, 180,
he died in Pannonia.
pairs.neutral_text: Marcus Aurelius traveled with his wife Faustina, but she died during the trip. When he returned, he held a triumph ceremony in 176 CE. Right after this, he went to Germany to continue fighting wars there. His military campaigns were successful. However, the stress and difficulties of recent years had weakened his already poor health, and he died in Pannonia on March 17, 180 CE.

pairs.stoic_text:
The good emperor was not spared domestic troubles. Faustina had borne
him several children, of whom he was passionately fond. Their innocent
faces may still be seen in many a sculpture gallery, recalling with odd
effect the dreamy countenance of their father. But they died one by
one, and when Marcus came to his own end only one of his sons still
lived--the weak and worthless Commodus. On his father's death Commodus,
who succeeded him, undid the work of many campaigns by a hasty and
unwise peace; and his reign of twelve years proved him to be a ferocious
and bloodthirsty tyrant. Scandal has made free with the name of Faustina
herself, who is accused not only of unfaithfulness, but of intriguing
with Cassius and egging him on to his fatal rebellion, it must be
admitted that these charges rest on no sure evidence; and the emperor,
at all events, loved her dearly, nor ever felt the slightest qualm of
suspicion.
pairs.neutral_text:
The emperor Marcus faced problems at home. His wife Faustina had given birth to several children, and he loved them deeply. Their faces can still be seen in ancient sculptures today, and they looked like their father. However, the children died one after another. When Marcus died, only one son remained alive - Commodus, who was weak and worthless. After his father's death, Commodus became emperor and quickly made a bad peace deal that ruined the results of many military campaigns. He ruled for twelve years and was a cruel dictator who enjoyed violence.

People also spread rumors about Faustina, claiming she was unfaithful to her husband and that she worked with a man named Cassius to encourage his rebellion against the emperor. However, there is no solid proof of these accusations. Marcus loved his wife and never suspected her of wrongdoing.

pairs.stoic_text:
To a thoughtful mind such a religion as that of Rome would give small
satisfaction. Its legends were often childish or impossible; its
teaching had little to do with morality. The Roman religion was in fact
of the nature of a bargain: men paid certain sacrifices and rites, and
the gods granted their favour, irrespective of right or wrong. In this
case all devout souls were thrown back upon philosophy, as they had
been, though to a less extent, in Greece. There were under the early
empire two rival schools which practically divided the field between
them, Stoicism and Epicureanism. The ideal set before each was
nominally much the same. The Stoics aspired to ἁπάθεια, the repression
of all emotion, and the Epicureans to ἀταραξία, freedom from all
disturbance; yet in the upshot the one has become a synonym of stubborn
endurance, the other for unbridled licence. With Epicureanism we have
nothing to do now; but it will be worth while to sketch the history and
tenets of the Stoic sect.
pairs.neutral_text:
Smart people found Roman religion unsatisfying. The stories were often silly or unbelievable, and the religion didn't teach much about right and wrong behavior. Roman religion worked like a business deal: people performed certain sacrifices and ceremonies, and in return the gods would help them, regardless of whether the people were good or bad.

Because of this, people who wanted deeper meaning turned to philosophy, just as had happened in Greece (though less so there). During the early Roman Empire, two main philosophical schools competed with each other: Stoicism and Epicureanism. Both schools had similar stated goals. The Stoics wanted to eliminate all emotions, and the Epicureans wanted to be free from all troubles. However, over time Stoicism became associated with tough endurance, while Epicureanism became linked with uncontrolled indulgence. This text will not discuss Epicureanism, but it will explain the history and beliefs of Stoicism.

pairs.stoic_text:
Zeno, the founder of Stoicism, was born in Cyprus at some date unknown,
but his life may be said roughly to be between the years 350 and 250
B.C. Cyprus has been from time immemorial a meeting-place of the East
and West, and although we cannot grant any importance to a possible
strain of Phoenician blood in him (for the Phœnicians were no
philosophers), yet it is quite likely that through Asia Minor he may
have come in touch with the Far East. He studied under the cynic
Crates, but he did not neglect other philosophical systems. After many
years' study he opened his own school in a colonnade in Athens called
the Painted Porch, or Stoa, which gave the Stoics their name. Next to
Zeno, the School of the Porch owes most to Chrysippus (280--207 b.c.),
who organised Stoicism into a system. Of him it was said,
pairs.neutral_text:
Zeno founded Stoicism. He was born in Cyprus, but we don't know the exact date. He lived approximately between 350 and 250 B.C. Cyprus was located where Eastern and Western cultures met. Zeno may have had some Phoenician ancestry, but this probably wasn't important since Phoenicians weren't known for philosophy. He possibly had contact with Far Eastern ideas through Asia Minor.

Zeno studied with Crates, who was a Cynic philosopher. He also learned about other philosophical systems. After studying for many years, he started his own school in Athens. He taught in a covered walkway called the Painted Porch, or "Stoa" in Greek. This is where the name "Stoics" came from.

After Zeno, the most important person for Stoicism was Chrysippus, who lived from 280 to 207 B.C. Chrysippus organized Stoic ideas into a complete philosophical system. People said about him,

pairs.stoic_text:
The Stoics regarded speculation as a means to an end and that end was,
as Zeno put it, to live consistently (ὁμολογουμένος ζῆν), or as it was
later explained, to live in conformity with nature (ὁμολογουμένος τῇ
φύσει ζῆν). This conforming of the life to nature was the Stoic idea of
Virtue. This dictum might easily be taken to mean that virtue consists
in yielding to each natural impulse; but that was very far from the
Stoic meaning. In order to live in accord with nature, it is necessary
to know what nature is; and to this end a threefold division of
philosophy is made—into _Physics_, dealing with the universe and its
laws, the problems of divine government and teleology; _Logic_, which
trains the mind to discern true from false; and _Ethics_, which applies
the knowledge thus gained and tested to practical life.
pairs.neutral_text: The Stoics viewed theoretical thinking as a tool to achieve a goal. According to Zeno, this goal was to live consistently, or as later Stoics explained, to live in agreement with nature. The Stoics believed that living according to nature was what virtue meant. This idea could be misunderstood to mean that virtue means following every natural urge, but that is not what the Stoics meant. To live according to nature, a person must understand what nature actually is. For this reason, the Stoics divided philosophy into three parts: Physics, which studies the universe and its laws, questions about divine control, and purpose; Logic, which teaches the mind to tell truth from falsehood; and Ethics, which uses this knowledge and applies it to everyday life.

pairs.stoic_text:
The Stoic system of physics was materialism with an infusion of
pantheism. In contradiction to Plato's view that the Ideas, or
Prototypes, of phenomena alone really exist, the Stoics held that
material objects alone existed; but immanent in the material universe
was a spiritual force which acted through them, manifesting itself
under many forms, as fire, æther, spirit, soul, reason, the ruling
principle.
pairs.neutral_text: The Stoics believed in a physical system that combined materialism and pantheism. Unlike Plato, who thought that only Ideas or Prototypes of things truly existed, the Stoics believed that only physical, material objects existed. However, they also believed that a spiritual force existed within the material universe and worked through these objects. This spiritual force appeared in different forms, including fire, ether, spirit, soul, reason, and the ruling principle.

pairs.stoic_text:
The universe, then, is God, of whom the popular gods are manifestations;
while legends and myths are allegorical. The soul of man is thus an
emanation from the godhead, into whom it will eventually be re-absorbed.
The divine ruling principle makes all things work together for good,
but for the good of the whole. The highest good of man is consciously
to work with God for the common good, and this is the sense in which
the Stoic tried to live in accord with nature. In the individual it
is virtue alone which enables him to do this; as Providence rules the
universe, so virtue in the soul must rule man.
pairs.neutral_text: According to this view, the universe is God, and popular gods are just different forms of this single divine being. Religious stories and myths are symbolic rather than literal. Human souls come from this divine source and will return to it after death. A divine force controls everything to benefit the whole universe, not necessarily individuals. The best thing humans can do is work together with this divine force for the common good - this is what Stoics meant by living according to nature. Individual virtue is what makes this possible. Just as divine providence controls the universe, virtue should control a person's actions and decisions.

pairs.stoic_text:
Such is the system which underlies the Meditations of Marcus Aurelius.
Some knowledge of it is necessary to the right understanding of the
book, but for us the chief interest lies elsewhere. We do not come to
Marcus Aurelius for a treatise on Stoicism. He is no head of a school to
lay down a body of doctrine for students; he does not even contemplate
that others should read what he writes. His philosophy is not an eager
intellectual inquiry, but more what we should call religious feeling.
The uncompromising stiffness of Zeno or Chrysippus is softened and
transformed by passing through a nature reverent and tolerant, gentle
and free from guile; the grim resignation which made life possible to
the Stoic sage becomes in him almost a mood of aspiration. His book
records the innermost thoughts of his heart, set down to ease it, with
such moral maxims and reflections as may help him to bear the burden of
duty and the countless annoyances of a busy life.
pairs.neutral_text:
This is the philosophical system behind Marcus Aurelius's Meditations. You need to understand some of it to properly read the book, but the main interest for us is something else. We don't read Marcus Aurelius to learn about Stoicism. He wasn't a school leader teaching students a set of beliefs, and he didn't expect other people to read what he wrote. His philosophy wasn't an intense academic study, but more like what we would call religious feelings.

The harsh rigidity of earlier Stoics like Zeno or Chrysippus became softer and changed when it went through Marcus Aurelius, who was respectful, tolerant, gentle, and honest. The tough acceptance that helped Stoic philosophers deal with life became almost hopeful in his hands. His book contains his most private thoughts, written down to comfort himself, along with moral advice and ideas that could help him handle his responsibilities and the many frustrations of a busy life.

pairs.stoic_text:
One so gentle towards a foe was sure to be a good friend; and indeed his
pages are full of generous gratitude to those who had served him. In his
First Book he sets down to account all the debts due to his kinsfolk
and teachers. To his grandfather he owed his own gentle spirit, to
his father shamefastness and courage; he learnt of his mother to be
religious and bountiful and single-minded. Rusticus did not work in
vain, if he showed his pupil that his life needed amending. Apollonius
taught him simplicity, reasonableness, gratitude, a love of true
liberty. So the list runs on; every one he had dealings with seems
to have given him something good, a sure proof of the goodness of his
nature, which thought no evil.
pairs.neutral_text: Someone who treated enemies with kindness would naturally be a good friend. Marcus Aurelius's writings show his appreciation for people who helped him. In his First Book, he lists what he owed to his family and teachers. His grandfather taught him to be gentle, his father taught him modesty and courage, and his mother taught him to be religious, generous, and focused. Rusticus helped him see that he needed to improve his life. Apollonius taught him to be simple, reasonable, grateful, and to love true freedom. The list continues this way - everyone he interacted with appears to have taught him something valuable. This shows he had a good nature and didn't think badly of others.

pairs.stoic_text:
Profound as philosophy these _Meditations_ certainly are not; but Marcus
Aurelius was too sincere not to see the essence of such things as
came within his experience. Ancient religions were for the most
part concerned with outward things. Do the necessary rites, and you
propitiate the gods; and these rites were often trivial, sometimes
violated right feeling or even morality. Even when the gods stood on the
side of righteousness, they were concerned with the act more than with
the intent. But Marcus Aurelius knows that what the heart is full of,
the man will do. 'Such as thy thoughts and ordinary cogitations are,' he
says, 'such will thy mind be in time.' And every page of the book shows
us that he knew thought was sure to issue in act. He drills his soul, as
it were, in right principles, that when the time comes, it may be guided
by them. To wait until the emergency is to be too late.
pairs.neutral_text: The *Meditations* are not deep philosophy, but Marcus Aurelius was honest enough to understand the basic truths of what he experienced. Most ancient religions focused on external actions. If you performed the required ceremonies, you would satisfy the gods. These ceremonies were often unimportant and sometimes went against proper feelings or morality. Even when the gods supported what was right, they cared more about what people did than why they did it. But Marcus Aurelius understood that people act based on what they truly believe. He wrote that your mind becomes shaped by your regular thoughts and ideas. Throughout the book, he shows he knew that thoughts lead to actions. He trained his mind in correct principles so that when difficult situations arose, these principles would guide him. Waiting until a crisis happens to develop these principles is too late.

pairs.stoic_text:
He sees also the true essence of happiness. 'If happiness did consist
in pleasure, how came notorious robbers, impure abominable livers,
parricides, and tyrants, in so large a measure to have their part of
pleasures?' He who had all the world's pleasures at command can write
thus 'A happy lot and portion is, good inclinations of the soul, good
desires, good actions.'
pairs.neutral_text: He also understands what happiness really is. He asks: if happiness were just about pleasure, then why do criminals, people who live badly, those who kill their parents, and dictators also experience so much pleasure? Even though this person had access to all the world's pleasures, he could still write: "True happiness comes from having a good character, wanting good things, and doing good deeds."

pairs.stoic_text:
Truly a rare opportunity was given to Marcus Aurelius of showing what
the mind can do in despite of circumstances. Most peaceful of warriors,
a magnificent monarch whose ideal was quiet happiness in home life, bent
to obscurity yet born to greatness, the loving father of children who
died young or turned out hateful, his life was one paradox. That nothing
might lack, it was in camp before the face of the enemy that he passed
away and went to his own place.
pairs.neutral_text: Marcus Aurelius had an unusual chance to demonstrate how mental strength can overcome difficult situations. He was a peaceful person who had to fight wars, a powerful emperor who preferred simple family life, someone who wanted to stay private but was forced into a prominent role, and a caring father whose children either died early or became hostile toward him. His life was full of contradictions. To complete this pattern of irony, he died in a military camp while facing enemies, rather than at home.

pairs.stoic_text:
The following is a list of the chief English translations of Marcus
Aurelius: (1) By Meric Casaubon, 1634; (2) Jeremy Collier, 1701; (3)
James Thomson, 1747; (4) R. Graves, 1792; (5) H. McCormac, 1844; (6)
George Long, 1862; (7) G. H. Rendall, 1898; and (8) J. Jackson, 1906.
Renan’s “Marc-Aurèle”—in his “History of the Origins of Christianity,”
which appeared in 1882—is the most vital and original book to be had
relating to the time of Marcus Aurelius. Pater’s “Marius the Epicurean”
forms another outside commentary, which is of service in the
imaginative attempt to create again the period.
pairs.neutral_text:
Here are the main English translations of Marcus Aurelius's works:

1. Meric Casaubon, 1634
2. Jeremy Collier, 1701
3. James Thomson, 1747
4. R. Graves, 1792
5. H. McCormac, 1844
6. George Long, 1862
7. G. H. Rendall, 1898
8. J. Jackson, 1906

Two other useful books about Marcus Aurelius's time period are:

- Renan's "Marc-Aurèle" from his "History of the Origins of Christianity" (1882) - this is the best modern book about Marcus Aurelius's era
- Pater's "Marius the Epicurean" - this book also helps readers understand what life was like during that time period

pairs.stoic_text:
Wherein Antoninus recordeth, What and of whom, whether Parents, Friends,
or Masters; by their good examples, or good advice and counsel, he had
learned:
pairs.neutral_text:
Here is the text rewritten in plain language:

In this section, Antoninus lists what he learned and from whom he learned it - whether from his parents, friends, or teachers. He describes how their good examples and advice taught him various lessons.

pairs.stoic_text:
ANTONINUS Book vi. Num. xlviii. Whensoever thou wilt rejoice thyself,
think and meditate upon those good parts and especial gifts, which thou
hast observed in any of them that live with thee:
pairs.neutral_text: When you want to feel happy, think about the good qualities and special talents you have noticed in the people around you.

pairs.stoic_text:
as industry in one, in another modesty, in another bountifulness, in
another some other thing. For nothing can so much rejoice thee, as
the resemblances and parallels of several virtues, eminent in the
dispositions of them that live with thee, especially when all at once,
as it were, they represent themselves unto thee. See therefore, that
thou have them always in a readiness.
pairs.neutral_text: Different people excel in different virtues: some are hardworking, others are humble, others are generous, and still others have different strengths. Nothing should make you happier than noticing these various virtues in the people around you, particularly when you can see several virtues displayed at the same time. Therefore, make sure you always keep these examples in mind.

pairs.stoic_text:
I. Of my grandfather Verus I have learned to be gentle and meek, and to
refrain from all anger and passion. From the fame and memory of him that
begot me I have learned both shamefastness and manlike behaviour. Of my
mother I have learned to be religious, and bountiful; and to forbear,
not only to do, but to intend any evil; to content myself with a spare
diet, and to fly all such excess as is incidental to great wealth. Of my
great-grandfather, both to frequent public schools and auditories, and
to get me good and able teachers at home; and that I ought not to think
much, if upon such occasions, I were at excessive charges.
pairs.neutral_text: I. From my grandfather Verus, I learned to be gentle and calm, and to avoid anger and strong emotions. From the reputation and memory of my father, I learned to be modest and to act like a man. From my mother, I learned to be religious and generous, and to avoid not just doing evil things but even thinking about them. She also taught me to eat simply and avoid the excesses that come with being wealthy. From my great-grandfather, I learned to attend public schools and lectures, and to hire good teachers for private instruction at home. He also taught me not to worry about spending a lot of money on education.

pairs.stoic_text:
II. Of him that brought me up, not to be fondly addicted to either of
the two great factions of the coursers in the circus, called Prasini,
and Veneti: nor in the amphitheatre partially to favour any of the
gladiators, or fencers, as either the Parmularii, or the Secutores.
Moreover, to endure labour; nor to need many things; when I have
anything to do, to do it myself rather than by others; not to meddle
with many businesses; and not easily to admit of any slander.
pairs.neutral_text:
**II. From my adoptive father, I learned:**

Not to become obsessed with either of the two main chariot racing teams in the circus (the Greens and the Blues), and not to pick favorites among the different types of gladiators in the arena.

I also learned to work hard, to live simply without needing many possessions, to do things myself instead of having others do them for me, to avoid getting involved in too many projects at once, and to not believe gossip or rumors about people.

pairs.stoic_text:
III. Of Diognetus, not to busy myself about vain things, and not easily
to believe those things, which are commonly spoken, by such as take upon
them to work wonders, and by sorcerers, or prestidigitators, and
impostors; concerning the power of charms, and their driving out of
demons, or evil spirits; and the like. Not to keep quails for the game;
nor to be mad after such things. Not to be offended with other men's
liberty of speech, and to apply myself unto philosophy. Him also I must
thank, that ever I heard first Bacchius, then Tandasis and Marcianus,
and that I did write dialogues in my youth; and that I took liking to
the philosophers' little couch and skins, and such other things, which
by the Grecian discipline are proper to those who profess philosophy.
pairs.neutral_text:
**From Diognetus I learned:**

• Not to waste time on pointless activities
• Not to believe people who claim they can perform miracles, magic, cast spells, or remove evil spirits
• Not to get involved in quail fighting or become obsessed with such entertainments
• Not to take offense when others speak freely
• To pursue philosophy
• I'm grateful he introduced me to the teachings of Bacchius, then Tandasis and Marcianus
• Because of him, I wrote philosophical dialogues when I was young
• He helped me appreciate the simple lifestyle of philosophers - their basic furniture, plain clothing, and other aspects of Greek philosophical tradition

pairs.stoic_text:
VII. From Alexander the Grammarian, to be un-reprovable myself, and not
reproachfully to reprehend any man for a barbarism, or a solecism, or
any false pronunciation, but dextrously by way of answer, or testimony,
or confirmation of the same matter (taking no notice of the word) to
utter it as it should have been spoken; or by some other such close and
indirect admonition, handsomely and civilly to tell him of it.
pairs.neutral_text: **VII. From Alexander the Grammarian:** I learned to avoid making mistakes myself and not to criticize others harshly for grammar errors, mispronunciations, or incorrect word usage. Instead, I should correct people indirectly - by using the correct word naturally in my response, or by repeating what they meant to say in the proper way, without drawing attention to their mistake. This allows me to help them politely and respectfully.

pairs.stoic_text:
VIII. Of Fronto, to how much envy and fraud and hypocrisy the state of a
tyrannous king is subject unto, and how they who are commonly called
εὐπατρίδαι, _i.e._ nobly born, are in some sort incapable, or void
of natural affection.
pairs.neutral_text:
**8. What Fronto taught about tyrannical rulers and aristocrats**

From Fronto, I learned two things:

1. Tyrannical kings must deal with a lot of jealousy, dishonesty, and false behavior from others.

2. People who are called "eupatridai" (meaning those born into noble families) often lack normal human feelings and care for others.

pairs.stoic_text:
IX. Of Alexander the Platonic, not often nor without great necessity to
say, or to write to any man in a letter, 'I am not at leisure'; nor in
this manner still to put off those duties, which we owe to our friends
and acquaintances (to every one in his kind) under pretence of urgent
affairs.
pairs.neutral_text: 9. From Alexander the Platonist: Don't frequently tell people "I don't have time" or write it in letters unless it's absolutely necessary. Don't use the excuse of being busy to avoid your responsibilities to friends and other people you know.

pairs.stoic_text:
X. Of Catulus, not to contemn any friend's expostulation, though unjust,
but to strive to reduce him to his former disposition: freely and
heartily to speak well of all my masters upon any occasion, as it is
reported of Domitius, and Athenodotus: and to love my children with true
affection.
pairs.neutral_text: 10. From Catulus: Don't dismiss a friend's complaints, even if they seem unfair. Instead, try to restore your relationship to how it was before. Speak positively about your teachers whenever you have the chance, following the example of Domitius and Athenodotus. Love your children genuinely.

pairs.stoic_text:
XI. From my brother Severus, to be kind and loving to all them of my
house and family; by whom also I came to the knowledge of Thrasea and
Helvidius, and Cato, and Dio, and Brutus. He it was also that did put me
in the first conceit and desire of an equal commonwealth, administered
by justice and equality; and of a kingdom wherein should be regarded
nothing more than the good and welfare of the subjects. Of him also,
to observe a constant tenor, (not interrupted, with any other cares and
distractions,) in the study and esteem of philosophy: to be bountiful
and liberal in the largest measure; always to hope the best; and to
be confident that my friends love me. In whom I moreover observed open
dealing towards those whom he reproved at any time, and that his friends
might without all doubt or much observation know what he would, or would
not, so open and plain was he.
pairs.neutral_text:
**XI. From my brother Severus, I learned several important things:**

I learned to be kind and loving to my household and family members. He introduced me to the writings and ideas of Thrasea, Helvidius, Cato, Dio, and Brutus. He taught me about the concept of a fair government based on justice and equality, and about leadership that prioritizes the welfare of citizens above all else.

From him I also learned to maintain consistent focus on studying and valuing philosophy without getting distracted by other concerns. He showed me how to be generous, always expect good outcomes, and trust that my friends care about me. I noticed that he was direct and honest when criticizing people, and his friends always knew exactly where they stood with him because he communicated so clearly and openly.

pairs.stoic_text:
XVI. Whatsoever I am, is either flesh, or life, or that which we
commonly call the mistress and overruling part of man; reason. Away with
thy books, suffer not thy mind any more to be distracted, and carried to
and fro; for it will not be; but as even now ready to die, think little
of thy flesh: blood, bones, and a skin; a pretty piece of knit and
twisted work, consisting of nerves, veins and arteries; think no more of
it, than so. And as for thy life, consider what it is; a wind; not one
constant wind neither, but every moment of an hour let out, and sucked
in again. The third, is thy ruling part; and here consider; Thou art an
old man; suffer not that excellent part to be brought in subjection, and
to become slavish: suffer it not to be drawn up and down with
unreasonable and unsociable lusts and motions, as it were with wires and
nerves; suffer it not any more, either to repine at anything now
present, or to fear and fly anything to come, which the destiny hath
appointed thee.
pairs.neutral_text: **XVI.** Whatever I am consists of three parts: my body, my life, or what we usually call the controlling part of a person - reason. Stop reading books and don't let your mind get distracted and pulled in different directions anymore, because it won't help. Since you're close to death, don't think much about your body: it's just blood, bones, and skin - a complex structure made of nerves, veins, and arteries. Don't think of it as more than that. As for your life, consider what it actually is: like air that isn't even constant, but is breathed in and out every moment. The third part is your reasoning mind, and here's what to consider: You are an old man. Don't let that important part become controlled by others or enslaved. Don't let it be manipulated by irrational and antisocial desires and impulses. Don't let it complain about present circumstances or fear future events that fate has planned for you.

pairs.stoic_text:
I. Remember how long thou hast already put off these things, and how
often a certain day and hour as it were, having been set unto thee by
the gods, thou hast neglected it. It is high time for thee to understand
the true nature both of the world, whereof thou art a part; and of that
Lord and Governor of the world, from whom, as a channel from the spring,
thou thyself didst flow: and that there is but a certain limit of time
appointed unto thee, which if thou shalt not make use of to calm and
allay the many distempers of thy soul, it will pass away and thou with
it, and never after return.
pairs.neutral_text: I. Think about how long you have already delayed these important matters, and how many times you have ignored specific deadlines that circumstances have given you. You need to understand two things: first, the real nature of the world that you are part of, and second, the nature of the power that governs the world, which is your source. You have a limited amount of time available to you. If you don't use this time to resolve your inner problems and find peace of mind, your time will run out, you will die, and you won't get another chance.

pairs.stoic_text:
II. Let it be thy earnest and incessant care as a Roman and a man to
perform whatsoever it is that thou art about, with true and unfeigned
gravity, natural affection, freedom and justice: and as for all other
cares, and imaginations, how thou mayest ease thy mind of them. Which
thou shalt do; if thou shalt go about every action as thy last action,
free from all vanity, all passionate and wilful aberration from reason,
and from all hypocrisy, and self-love, and dislike of those things,
which by the fates or appointment of God have happened unto thee. Thou
seest that those things, which for a man to hold on in a prosperous
course, and to live a divine life, are requisite and necessary, are not
many, for the gods will require no more of any man, that shall but keep
and observe these things.
pairs.neutral_text: **II.** As a Roman citizen and human being, focus constantly on doing whatever task you're working on with genuine seriousness, kindness, honesty, and fairness. Stop worrying about other concerns and distracting thoughts. You can do this by treating each action as if it were your final one, avoiding show-off behavior, emotional outbursts, unreasonable decisions, fake behavior, selfishness, and resentment about events that fate or God has caused in your life. You can see that the requirements for living successfully and virtuously are actually few in number. The gods don't ask for more than this from anyone who follows these principles.

pairs.stoic_text:
III. Do, soul, do; abuse and contemn thyself; yet a while and the time
for thee to respect thyself, will be at an end. Every man's happiness
depends from himself, but behold thy life is almost at an end, whiles
affording thyself no respect, thou dost make thy happiness to consist in
the souls, and conceits of other men.
pairs.neutral_text: **3. Take action now and stop criticizing yourself.** You won't have much time left to value yourself properly. Each person's happiness comes from within themselves. However, your life is nearly over, and instead of respecting yourself, you're basing your happiness on what other people think and believe about you.

pairs.stoic_text:
IV. Why should any of these things that happen externally, so much
distract thee? Give thyself leisure to learn some good thing, and cease
roving and wandering to and fro. Thou must also take heed of another
kind of wandering, for they are idle in their actions, who toil and
labour in this life, and have no certain scope to which to direct all
their motions, and desires. V. For not observing the state of another
man's soul, scarce was ever any man known to be unhappy. Tell whosoever
they be that intend not, and guide not by reason and discretion the
motions of their own souls, they must of necessity be unhappy.
pairs.neutral_text:
**Section IV:** Why do external events upset you so much? Take time to learn something valuable instead of constantly moving from one thing to another without purpose. You should also avoid a different type of aimlessness - people who stay busy with work and activities but have no clear goal to guide their actions and wants.

**Section V:** People rarely become unhappy by paying attention to what others are thinking or feeling. However, anyone who doesn't use reason and good judgment to control their own thoughts and emotions will definitely be unhappy.
